Award.AwardTitle: Workshops on Mathematical Challenges in Many-Body Physics and Quantum Information
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation for three workshops and a school that are part of the thematic program "Mathematical Challenges in Many-Body Physics and Quantum Information" to be held at Centre de Recherches Mathematiques (CRM) located in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. The first workshop, "Quantum information and quantum statistical mechanics", will be held October 15-19, 2018. The school "Mathematics of Non-equilibrium Statistical Mechanics" will be held October 24-26, 2018. The scond workshop, "Entropic fluctuation relations in mathematics and physics" will be held October 29-November 2, 2018. The third workshop, "Spectral theory of quasi-periodic and random operators" will be held November 13-16, 2018.

The individual workshops and school focus on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of mathematical physics and quantum information science. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference series. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at the thematic conference webpage: http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/Quantum2018/index.php/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported the participation of sixteen US-based researchers, of which the majority were junior researchers in the formative stages of their careers, in three workshops held in October and November 2018 at the Centre de Recherche Mathematique (Montreal) in the framework of a three-month Thematic Program on Mathematical Challenges in Many-Body Physics and Quantum Information. The first workshop (October 15-19) was organized by Fernando Brandão (Caltech), Bruno Nachtergaele (UC Davis), Claude-Alain Pillet (U Toulon), and Michael Wolf (TU Munich) and was devoted to the mathematics at the intersection of Quantum Information and Quantum Statistical Mechanics. The second workshop covered new results in Entropic Fluctuation Relations in Mathematics and Physics. It organizers were Vojkan Jakšic (McGill), Claude-Alain Pillet (Toulon), and Christian Maes (Leuven). A third workshop was devoted to the Spectral Theory of Quasi-Periodic and Random Operators and was organized by Jonathan Breuer (Hebrew University of Jerusalem), Milivoje Lukic (Rice), Simone Warzel (TU Munich), and David Damanik (Rice). In addition, there was also a school on the Mathematics of Non-equilibrium Statistical Mechanics organized by Jean-Marie Barbaroux (Toulon), Horia Cornean (Aalborg),  Vojkan Jaksic (McGill), Flora Koukiou (Cergy-Pontoise), and Armen Shirikyan (Cergy-Pontoise).

The success of the workshops and the school was evident from the lively participation by the junior researchers who greatly benefited from the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the state-of-the-art in the mathematical analysis of quantum systems.  Ground breaking research presented in each workshop included the following topics: 1) quantum spin systems, spectral gaps, quantum entropy, entanglement and coherence, dynamics and non-equilibrium, disordered systems and localization, classification of phases, and topological states of matter and indices; 2) statistics of fluctuations of entropic quantities in physical systems out of thermal equilibrium; 3) localization, eigenvalue statistics, and random matrices.
